sub_topic: Finding the height of objects using trigonometry
message_1: A building cast a shadow of 30 meters during a time when the angle of elevation of the sun was 60 degrees. Find the height of the building rounded to the nearest meter.
message_2:
To find the height of the building, we can use the tangent function in trigonometry. The tangent of an angle in a right triangle is the ratio of the length of the side opposite the angle to the length of the side adjacent to the angle. In this case, the angle of elevation of the sun is 60 degrees, the shadow (adjacent side) is 30 meters, and we want to find the height of the building (opposite side).

We can set up the equation:

tan(60°) = height / 30

To find the height, we can multiply both sides of the equation by 30:

height = 30 * tan(60°)

The tangent of 60 degrees is √3, so:

height = 30 * √3 ≈ 51.96

Rounded to the nearest meter, the height of the building is approximately 52 meters.
